case_vignette: A 30-year-old Hispanic woman presents with her 1-year-old son, concerned that he has only small amounts of thin, wispy hair on his head and has none anywhere else on his body. She notes that he does not yet have any teeth, but has a large forehead and ears. He has been irritable and crying for the past day. She reveals a personal history of very high body temperature at times during the summer and says she customarily stays indoors with the air conditioning on, especially in the summer. On physical examination, she has sparse hair on her scalp and eyebrows, as well as eczematous patches on her bilateral lower extremities.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm not facing any symptoms today, but my 1-year-old son has very little hair and has no teeth, plus a large forehead and ears, and he's been quite irritable and crying since yesterday.
Is there a family history of similar symptoms or conditions?
Yes, I personally experience having very little hair and tend to get overheated easily, especially in the summer, so I stay indoors with air conditioning.
Has your son been diagnosed with any medical conditions previously?
No, he hasn't been diagnosed with any medical conditions.
Is there a history of similar symptoms in any other family members?
There's no more information provided about other family members having similar symptoms.
**Final Diagnosis:** Cornelia de Lange syndrome
